title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" is designated for reducing public debt through the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by adding a new part for the designation of amounts for debt reduction. Every individual with adjusted income tax liability can designate up to 10% of their liability to reduce public debt. This designation must be made when filing the tax return and is subtracted from the income tax liability. Part IX. Designation for reduction of public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DEBT REDUCTION TRUST FUND. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a section on the Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay off federal government obligations included in the public debt. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund, and any obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund in the Treasury of the United States pays off federal government obligations in the public debt. Obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired. A new item is added to the table of sections for the subchapter. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund pays off federal government obligations in the public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the enactment of this Act. Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a new section for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration procedures are mandated within 15 days after Congress adjourns, following the same day as any prior sequestration. The Department of the Treasury estimates the aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code for the last taxable year, adjusted for discretionary spending reductions and deficit changes. The sequestration procedures involve reducing budgetary resources in accounts by a uniform percentage to address deficit changes resulting from direct spending legislation. Certain accounts are exempt from these reductions, such as benefits payable to the old-age. The reduction of obligational authority under this section must be permanent. No order issued under this part can reduce benefits for the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance program, payments for net interest, or certain specified accounts like the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation funds. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include reports on income tax designated by the Department of Treasury to Congress. This amendment also includes sequestration to reduce the public debt. The Department of Treasury will report to Congress on the estimated income tax designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, there will be sequestration to reduce the public debt, with reports outlining the aggregate amount designated for the last taxable year and the reductions required under section 253A. The Department of Treasury will report to Congress on the estimated income tax designated under section 6097 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sequestration will be implemented to reduce the public debt, with reports detailing the reductions required under section 253A and the sequestration percentage needed to achieve the reduction. The final reports will include all information from the public debt taxation designation report required on May 1. Final reports will include all information from the public debt taxation designation report required on May 1. The amendments made by this section shall cease to have any effect after the first fiscal year during which there is no public debt.
